raw.title: Mein Kampf
raw.author: Hitler
contexts: Mein Kampf is the complete manifesto of a political programme.
commentaries: The author cites Mein Kampf as the definitive ideological text of Nazism, contrasting its systematic philosophy with the ideological incoherence of Italian Fascism.

goodreads_match.title: Mein Kampf
goodreads_match.description: Madman, tyrant, animal - history has given Adolf Hitler many names. In Mein Kampf (My Struggle), often called the Nazi bible, Hitler describes his life, frustrations, ideals, and dreams. Born to an impoverished couple in a small town in Austria, the young Adolf grew up with the fervent desire to become a painter. The death of his parents and outright rejection from art schools in Vienna forced him into underpaid work as a labourer. During the First World War, Hitler served in the infantry and was decorated....

raw.author: Pat Robertson
contexts: The latest example of this obsession with conspiracies is Pat Robertson’s book The New World Order.
commentaries: The author cites Pat Robertson’s book as a contemporary manifestation of the Ur-Fascist obsession with international conspiracies, particularly as a tool for xenophobic mobilization.

raw.author: Giovanni Gentile
contexts: The article on Fascism signed by Mussolini for the Enciclopedia Treccani was written or fundamentally inspired by Giovanni Gentile, but it reflected a late-Hegelian notion of the 'ethical and absolute state' that Mussolini never completely realised.
commentaries: The author attributes the philosophical framing of Fascism in the Enciclopedia Treccani to Gentile, emphasizing that Mussolini himself lacked a coherent philosophy and merely adopted Gentile’s Hegelian ideas rhetorically.

raw.author: Antonio Gramsci
contexts: Gramsci remained in prison until his death, Matteotti and the Rosselli brothers were murdered, the free press suppressed, the labour unions dismantled, and political dissidents confined to remote islands.
commentaries: The author mentions Gramsci as a victim of Fascist repression, using his fate to illustrate the regime’s intolerance despite its apparent ideological chaos.

raw.author: Julius Evola
contexts: Add the cult of Celtic mythology and the mysticism of the Grail (completely extraneous to official Fascism), and you get one of the most respected gurus of Fascism, Julius Evola.
The most important theorist of the new Italian right, Julius Evola, mixed the Grail with the Protocols of the Elders of Zion, and alchemy with the Holy Roman Empire.
commentaries: The author references Julius Evola as an influential figure whose esoteric, non-official ideas were absorbed into broader Fascist thought, though not part of mainstream Italian Fascism.
The author cites Julius Evola as a key theorist whose syncretic ideology blended occult, traditionalist, and antisemitic elements to form a foundation for the Italian right.

raw.author: Joseph Goebbels
contexts: From the statement attributed to Goebbels (‘When I hear talk of culture, I take out my pistol’)
commentaries: The author cites Goebbels’ quoted remark to exemplify the Fascist disdain for intellectual and cultural critique as a form of weakness or betrayal.

raw.author: Wittgenstein
contexts: According to Wittgenstein, what happens with the notion of ‘Fascism’ is what happens with the notion of ‘play.’
I would say that the ideology of this censorship through noise can be expressed, with apologies to Wittgenstein, by saying, 'Whereof one cannot speak, thereof one must talk a great deal.'
commentaries: The author cites Wittgenstein’s concept of 'family resemblances' in games to explain how Fascism functions as a loosely defined category with overlapping but non-universal traits.
The author invokes Wittgenstein’s famous aphorism to reframe it as a critique of media overload, using it as a conceptual tool to describe how excessive speech obscures meaningful discourse.

raw.author: Orwell
contexts: 'Newspeak' was invented by Orwell in 1984, as the official language of Ingsoc, the English Socialist movement, but elements of Ur-Fascism are common to different forms of dictatorship.
commentaries: The author cites Orwell's 1984 as the origin of the term 'Newspeak' and draws a parallel between its use in totalitarian regimes and Ur-Fascist language control.

raw.title: For Whom the Bell Tolls
raw.author: Hemingway
contexts: If you reread Hemingway’s For Whom the Bell Tolls, you will discover that Robert Jordan identifies his enemies with the Fascists even when he is thinking of the Spanish Falangists.
commentaries: The author cites Hemingway’s novel as evidence that the term 'Fascist' was used broadly during the Spanish Civil War to describe enemy forces, even when they were technically Falangists.

goodreads_match.title: For Whom the Bell Tolls
goodreads_match.description:
From the cover of the first edition:
Into this great new novel--nearly twice as long as "A Farewell to Arms"--Ernest Hemingway has poured the fullness of his experience, the perfection of his art. A novel of wartime Spain, in which a young American and a Spanish girl live a lifetime of love and courage in four momentous days, it speaks with final and unforgettable power for the truth--the truth of war and life in our time.
With Robert Jordan already behind the enemy lines on his dangerous mission--to join f...

raw.author: Aristotle
contexts: from Aristotle onwards, philosophers have called prudence.
commentaries: The author references Aristotle as the origin of the classical philosophical concept of prudence (phronesis) as a cardinal virtue essential to ethical judgment.

raw.title: How to Spot a Fascist
raw.author: Umberto Eco
contexts: Umberto Eco: How to Spot a Fascist trans. Richard Dixon and Alastair McEwen
commentaries: The author cites Umberto Eco's work as the source of the essay, noting its translation history and publication context within Harvill Secker's series.

goodreads_match.title: Ur-Fascism
goodreads_match.description: An essay by Umberto Eco originally published in The New York Review of Books in 1995, titled 'Ur-Fascism,' which outlines 14 characteristics of fascist ideology. The cited text 'How to Spot a Fascist' is a popular paraphrase or adaptation of this essay, often circulated online and sometimes misattributed as a standalone work. The translation mentioned (Richard Dixon and Alastair McEwen) refers to later English-language publications of Eco's collected essays.

raw.author: Joseph de Maistre
contexts: the Italian right has recently widened its syllabus by putting together De Maistre, Guenon, and Gramsci
commentaries: The author mentions De Maistre as one of the thinkers incorporated into the Italian right’s ideological mix, highlighting the syncretic nature of their thought.

raw.author: Saint Augustine
contexts: you will even find Saint Augustine, who, as far as I know, was not a Fascist.
the example of Saint Augustine could still provide a good ideal for the world of politics and television.
commentaries: The author references Saint Augustine as an example of an unexpected and historically incongruous figure co-opted into New Age fascist-adjacent thought.
The author cites Saint Augustine as a moral and philosophical model for addressing the loss of silence in modern media and political culture.

raw.author: Franklin Delano Roosevelt
contexts: I yield the floor to Franklin Delano Roosevelt: 'The victory of the American people and their allies will be a victory against Fascism and the blind alley of despotism that it represents' (23 September 1944).

Once more I yield the floor to Roosevelt: 'I dare to say that if American democracy ceased to progress as a living force, seeking night and day by peaceful means to improve the condition of our citizens, the power of Fascism would grow in our country' (4 November 1938).
commentaries: The author quotes Roosevelt’s speech to illustrate how 'Fascism' was used as a unifying moral label during World War II, extending its application beyond Nazi Germany to encompass other authoritarian regimes.
The author quotes Roosevelt to underscore the fragility of democracy and the danger of complacency in the face of rising Fascism.

raw.author: René Guénon
contexts: the Italian right has recently widened its syllabus by putting together De Maistre, Guenon, and Gramsci
commentaries: The author cites Guénon as part of a deliberately incongruous grouping of thinkers, illustrating the eclectic and contradictory nature of contemporary right-wing syncretism.

raw.author: Ezra Pound
contexts: Add to Italian Fascism a dash of radical anti-Capitalism (which never appealed to Mussolini), and you get Ezra Pound.
commentaries: The author cites Ezra Pound as an example of a figure who blended Fascist aesthetics with radical economic ideas foreign to Mussolini’s regime, illustrating the flexible boundaries of Fascist identity.

raw.author: Franco Fortini
contexts: And now I should like to close with a poem by Franco Fortini: On the parapet of the bridge The heads of hanged men In the water of the fountain The drool of hanged men On the cobbles of the market The fingernails of men shot down On the dry grass of the meadow The teeth of men shot down Bite the air bite the stones Our flesh is the flesh of men no more Bite the air bite the stones Our hearts are the hearts of men no more.
commentaries: The author invokes Fortini's poem as a haunting memorial to victims of Fascism, using it to reinforce the moral imperative to remember and resist.

raw.author: Ionesco
contexts: Ionesco once said that only words count and all the rest is idle chatter.
commentaries: The author invokes Ionesco’s aphorism to support the argument that linguistic habits reveal underlying cultural sentiments, using it as a conceptual foundation for analyzing the use of the term 'Fascism'.
